The agitation for a course in
military training, which has been
carried on during the past six
months, now seems likely to be
crowned with definite and immediate results. Dean Brush himself
has announced that, in all .probability, Hopkins will have military
training within the year.
During the past week the Dean
has appeared before such classes as
4nglish Literature I and Philosophy I, which contain most of the
students of the University, and has
put before the men the question as
to whether or not they were desirous of embarking upon the contemplated course this spring. Those
who announced their readiness to
take such a course have affixed their
signatures to a statement to that
effect, and, in this manner, more
than a hundred names have already
been received.
It is felt by the Dean and others
of the faculty interested in military
training, that, if Hopkins is to have
such a course, it is advisable to install it as soon ag possible, and
thus to crystallize student sentiment, as well as to provide for the
smooth working of the drills and
maneuvers next year, when the
University will be located at Homewood.
The Board of Trustees has not
as yet taken official action upon the
question of the immediate installation of the course; it is as much to
show them how many students are
willing to go on record as ready to
devote two or three afternoons a
week to drilling, as for any other
reason, that the petitions have been
circulated. It is confidently expected, however, that the trustees
will approve the immediate establishment of the course.

presents itself is the obtaining the
consent of the War College at

It is extremely likely that Hopkins will have a chance to see and
hear Billy Sunday in person.
Ever since plans for his coming
to Baltimore were announced, •the
Young Men's Christian Association of this University has been
considering the feasibility of bringing the evangelist to Hopkins. During the last week, petitions have
been circulated throughout the University requesting the Board of
Trustees to grant the use of the
McCoy Hall for a talk by Mr. Sunday to the Hopkins students; and
there seems to be every reason to
believe that the request will be
granted.
The sentiment of the students is
apparently overwhelmingly in favor
of such a meeting and the great
majority of them have affixed their
signatures to a petition to the trustees for the use of McCoy Hall.
If McCoy Hall cannot be secured,
however, it is quite likely that Mr.
Sunday will speak in the chapel of
Levering Hall, although the latter
hall will not hold all those who
would probably be present.
Mr. Sunday, it is believed, would
readily respond to a request to address the students of this University. He has spoken in many colleges in cities in which he has conducted revivals, and has always expressed himself as pleased with the
reception he has received.
The chapel services this week
have been led by members of the
Sunday party, who have explained
the motives and methods of action
of the evangelist.

On account of the examinations,
the end of the big sales-check contest conducted by THE NEWS-LETTER, has been postponed from
March 8 to March 18. This will
give the contestants an opportunity
to accumulate more receipts and
will also give any new men who
desire to enter the contest a chance
to do so.
The one who passes into the
hands of the Business Managers of
THE NEWS-LETTER the highest
amount of sales-checks and receipted bills of purchases from
NEWS-LETTER advertisers will receive first prize. As yet the prizes
have not been announced, but it is
stated that they will be fine enough
to more than compensate the men
for the trouble of collecting the
checks. Every one who passes in
$15 worth of sales-checks will receive some kind of reward, theater
tickets, socks, ties, or the like.
The real purpose of the contest,
apart from the stimulation of interest in the student body, is to
show THE NEWS-LETTER advertisers just how much business they
get from Hopkins' men and their
families. If the Business Managers
of THE NEWS-LETTER can show
that Hopkins', representatives have
purchased just so much from
NEWS-LETTER advertisers, it makes
the getting of new ads easier and
the holding of old ones certain.
The contest closes at 12 o'clock
on Saturday, March 18. All saleschecks should be handed in to one
of the Business Managers as early
as possible on Saturday morning,
so that the managers will have time
to count., up the checks and determine the winners.

Games, held at Convention Hall, in
Washington, last Saturday night,
Hopkins made a very fair showing
considering that they left at home
several of their first-string men in
order that the novices might have
the experience of competing in the
open events. The Black and Blue
scored ten points winning firsts
the high-jump and shot-put,
while Virginia won the trophy with
eleven points. The coach had
planned to concentrate the energies
of the team in a one-mile relay
with Georgetown, and in the two
South Atlantic Championship
events. On arriving on the scene
of action, however, the team was
informed that, owing to some hitch
-in the management of the meet, the
Georgetown four were unprepared
to run. Hopkins then distributed
its men as best she could, and
managed to make a fairly good
showing.
The most exciting event was the
South Atlantic 2-mile run. Weeks,
running for the first time in a 2mile event, put up a beautiful fight,
setting the pace a large part of the
way and showing remarkably good
judgment. 1-le was beaten out in
the last hundred yards by Campbell, of Georgetown, who covered
the distance in 10 minutes and 10
seconds, which is unusually good
time for the track.
In the open quirter mile the Hopkins men were unable to overcome
the heavy handicaps, but in the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Association quarter, Uhler and Berkley, of Virginia, had an exciting
struggle. Uhler got the start and
stuck to the rail relentlessly, in spite
of a great deal of crowding on the
sharp turns. In the last straightaway, Berkley bested him by a yard,
while Strauss was a close third.
Strauss, however, was given second
place when the officials disqualified

of special interest, since only Hopkins and Virginia men took part.

work in the field events, each surpassing his former 'mark. Firor
was credited with 6 feet I inch, including his handicap, in the highjump. He shows promise of being
a valuable man in this event in the
spring contests. Iddings also bested his old mark in the shot-put, and
was credited with 46 feet, easily securing first place.

Mr. Youel B. Mirza, a graduate
student of the Political Science Department of this University, has
written an article entitled "The
Kurds: Their Character and Customs," for the March number of
the Review of Reviews.
The Kurds are a nomadic tribe of
north Persia and many of their
"Gutus" or _warriors have joined
the Turkish regiments in the present war. Since Mr. Mirza claims
Persia as a native land, he is able
to tell of this tribe as one who has
seen and associated with its members. The Kurds play the same
part in Persia as the gypsies do in
Mr. Mirza's
North America.
grandfather was a missionary
among these people and it is from
him that he gained much of his
knowledge of their characteristics.
The chief -reason for tlie Kurds
entering the war, says Mr. Mirza
in his article, was to get revenge
upon the Armenians, whom the
Turks were fighting. The. cause
of strife between them and the
Armenians is not one of religious
hatred as is commonly supposed,
but simply one of economic jealousy. The Armenians are a thrifty,
industrious and persevering race,
while the Kurds do no more work
than is necessary, preferring to live
in peace and laziness rather than
to labor. The Armenians are better
dressed and live in better circumstances than their neighbors, who
dwell in goat-skin tents in summer
and in mud villages in winter.
Moreover, the Armenians live *by
working in fields or factories; the
Kurds, on the other hand, exist by
plundering and slaughtering.
No people are more mistrusted
by the Persians and Turks, the article continues, than are the Kurds.
These people do not consider a
man's religion or standing; they
would rob a Turk as quickly as an
Armenian or a Greek. The only
large power which has any control
over them is Russia, which undertook their superveillance only after
the Ottoman Porte and the Persian
Shah had failed.
Among the two and a half million people of this tribe there is no
one who calls himself law-giver or
leader; no one who assumes the
authority of punishing a fellow
Kurd. Law with them is entirely
a private matter; each individual
considers himself his own ruler.
The Kurds love freedom and will
subject themselves to no one. A
young man is judged by the amount
of successful robberies and murders
he has committed and is often
charged by his parents to gain
name and respect for himself and
his family by this Method.
In contrast to their rough ways
is their most distinguishing characteristic—the great devotion
among the members of the families.

Pass through it but will not permit

There is an agitation at the University of Nebraska for the adoption of the Single Tax. The two
chief arguments given in its favor
by the editor of the Nebraskan are:

to all college students, to determine
those eligible for appointment to
the corps of Consular Assistants
and Student Interpreters in the
foreign service, is to take place in
Washington during the week of

The examination is the same for
the two corps and is of threefold
character—written, oral and physical. Two days are given to the
written examination, the eight subjects occurring in the following order : (I) International, Maritime
and Commercial Law;(2) Political
and Commercial Geography ; (3)
Arithmetic ; (4) one modern language, Spanish, French or German ; (5) Natural, Industrial and
Commercial Resources and Commerce of the United States; (6)
Political Economy ; (7) American
History, Government and Institutions; (8) Modern History (since
1850) of Europe, South Ante!ica
and the Far East.
Young unmarried men only are
examined for appointment to the
corps of Consular Assistants and
Student Interpreters, and only those
men designated are permitted to
take the examination. Traveling
and other expenses incurred in connection with the examination must
be paid by the candidates.
The corps of Consular Assistants
consists of forty men, who are assigned for duty in consular offices
by the Secretary of State. They
receive a salary of $1,000 a year for
the first three years of service, and
$200 additional each year thereafter until the maximum of $1,800
has been reached. Consular Assistants are eligible for promotion
to the post of Consular, the consular service being conducted on
the merit system.
Twenty-six student interpreters

promotion to the position of interpreter. Two years later there occurs another examination, and the

six years after entrance, ascertains
whether the candidates are qualified

southern trip and wish to meet
Hopkins among other .universities.

increase." As they can only take

support the same side of the question against each opponent. Their

arrangement is so satisfactory that
no thought of changing it has been
considered.

will meet the University of Virginia and the University of North
Carolina respectively, are hard at
work collecting all the material
available. Neither team anticipates
an easy victory over the men of the
southern universities, who are reported to be unusually good this

Mr. Youel B. Mirza, a graduate
student of the Political Science Department of this University, has
written an article entitled "The
Kurds: Their Character and Customs," for the March number of
the Review of Reviews.
The Kurds are a nomadic tribe of
north Persia and many of their
"Gutus" or _warriors have joined
the Turkish regiments in the present war. Since Mr. Mirza claims
Persia as a native land, he is able
to tell of this tribe as one who has
seen and associated with its members. The Kurds play the same
part in Persia as the gypsies do in
Mr. Mirza's
North America.
grandfather was a missionary
among these people and it is from
him that he gained much of his
knowledge of their characteristics.
The chief -reason for tlie Kurds
entering the war, says Mr. Mirza
in his article, was to get revenge
upon the Armenians, whom the
Turks were fighting. The. cause
of strife between them and the
Armenians is not one of religious
hatred as is commonly supposed,
but simply one of economic jealousy. The Armenians are a thrifty,
industrious and persevering race,
while the Kurds do no more work
than is necessary, preferring to live
in peace and laziness rather than
to labor. The Armenians are better
dressed and live in better circumstances than their neighbors, who
dwell in goat-skin tents in summer
and in mud villages in winter.
Moreover, the Armenians live *by
working in fields or factories; the
Kurds, on the other hand, exist by
plundering and slaughtering.
No people are more mistrusted
by the Persians and Turks, the article continues, than are the Kurds.
These people do not consider a
man's religion or standing; they
would rob a Turk as quickly as an
Armenian or a Greek. The only
large power which has any control
over them is Russia, which undertook their superveillance only after
the Ottoman Porte and the Persian
Shah had failed.
Among the two and a half million people of this tribe there is no
one who calls himself law-giver or
leader; no one who assumes the
authority of punishing a fellow
Kurd. Law with them is entirely
a private matter; each individual
considers himself his own ruler.
The Kurds love freedom and will
subject themselves to no one. A
young man is judged by the amount
of successful robberies and murders
he has committed and is often
charged by his parents to gain
name and respect for himself and
his family by this Method.
In contrast to their rough ways
is their most distinguishing characteristic—the great devotion
among the members of the families.

The beginning of the most modern era of chemistry dates from the
time of the announcement of Van't
Hoff's theory of'solutions. The

that .the molecules of a substance
dissolved in water exist in a condition which is similar to that of
the molecules of a gas. It has been
pointed out that Avogadro's conception of the molecular constitution of gases furnished the foundation for a rational explanation of
the laws of gases. The application
by Van't Hoff, of this same conception to the condition of the
molecules of a dissolved substance,'
has done much the same for the
phenomena of solutions. According to this conception the molecules of both gases and dissblved substances are moving about in all directions at enormous velocities.
Although the weight of a single

great number and high velocity exercise a considerable force when
their motion is restrained. In the
case of gases this kinetic energy of
the molecules, when restrained by
the walls of the containing vessel,
results in a thrust or pressure
against the walls of the container.
In the case of solutions this kinetic
energy of the dissolved molecules
is exhibited as osmotic pressure
when the restraining wall is a substance which will permit water to
Pass through it but will not permit
the passage of molecules of the dissolved substance. Osmotic pressure
has thus much the same relations to
solutions that the pressure of gases
has to gases.

a few rough measurements of osmotic pressure on record, and the

great. These have been obtained
with marked success.
